text.introduction1: Train judges to answer rulings in unfamiliar (random) situations
text.introduction2: The situations becomes challenging because of peer pressure, both from actors and spectators
text.introduction3: Community building (it’s fun and we learn together!)
text.introduction4: The scenarios are diverse and can test rules knowledge, diplomacy capabilities and investigation skills
text.introduction6: Each situation requires 2-4 participants: a judge, and depending on the scenario 1-2 players and/or a head judge (having four to six participants per group is 2.
text.introduction7: Encouraged, since people may have feedback even if they're not actively participating)
text.introduction8: Each group will use a dedicated app to generate the situation (some of the details are not available to all participants)
text.introduction9: The players set up a situation as described before they 'call' a judge (this usually requires some magic cards, so have some ready for each group)
text.introduction10: Player A is the one causing the judge call (the situation defines whether on purpose or not)
text.introduction11: If relevant, Player B may accuse Player A of cheating
text.introduction12: The Judge will answer the call
text.introduction13: After the situation is resolved, all participants (actors, judge, HJ and spectators) will discuss the situation and are welcome to give feedback
text.introduction15: At the end of the workshop you may gather all groups and have them share what they learned
